citation.article-title: Actinomadura bangladeshensis sp. nov. and Actinomadura chokoriensis sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Actinomadura bangladeshensis sp. nov.
Actinomadura bangladeshensis (ban.gla.desh.en′sis. N.L. fem. adj. bangladeshensis pertaining to Bangladesh, where the type strain was isolated).
Forms a well-developed, branched substrate mycelium.
Abundant aerial mycelium is present.
Spore chains (four to eight spores) are curved to slightly hooked and spores are oval to cylindrical with a rough surface.
Sporangia are not detected.

Good growth occurs on ISP media 3, 4, 5 (glycerol-asparagine agar) and 7, glucose-yeast extract, Hickey–Tresner agar, Waksman agar and oatmeal-nitrate agar; moderate growth occurs on glucose-asparagine agar, yeast extract-malt extract agar and Bennett agar; and poor growth occurs on nutrient agar, water agar and Seino agar.
Substrate mycelium colour is light wheat (2ea) to bamboo (2gc) on various agar media.
Pale pink to white aerial mycelium and abundant sporulation are found on ISP media 3, 4 and 7, Hickey–Tresner agar, Waksman agar and oatmeal-nitrate agar after 21 days incubation at 28 °C.
Soluble pigment is not produced.
Aerobic.
Gram-positive.
Growth occurs at pH 5.0–9.0.
The temperature range for growth is between 20 and 45 °C.
Production of melanoid pigments is negative.
Good growth occurs with 4 % NaCl.
The isomer of DAP is meso, and madurose, galactose, glucose and mannose occur in whole-cell hydrolysates.
The N-acyl type of muramic acid is acetyl.
Mycolic acids are absent.
The polar lipids include phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylinositol.
The major menaquinone is MK-9(H6); minor amounts of MK-9(H8) and MK-9(H4) are found.
Major fatty acids (>8.0 % of the total) are iso-C16 : 0, C17 : 0, C16 : 0, C15 : 0 and C17 : 1ω8c.
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 70.27 mol%.
The type strain, 3-46-b(3)T (=JCM 13933T =MTCC8057T), was isolated from sandy soil of Chokoria, Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh.
